text: JO MARCH, our heroine, hesitates. In the half-light of a dim hallway, she exhales and prepa her head bowed like a boxer about to go into the ring. Sh puts her hand on the doorknob. A pause, and then, she ope it onto a disorderly room. It is full of men. Some sit with their feet up on the des higher than their hats, which they do not remove for her. They smoke and read, hardly noticing that she has walked Jo walks through the desks, looking for one in particular
(clearing her throat) Excuse me. MR. DASHWOOD (the oldest, smokiest gentleman) looks at he
I was looking for the Weekly Volcano office... I wished to see Mr. Dashwood? Mr. Dashwood stares silently.

(nervous, presenting pages) A friend of mine desired me to offer a story, by her, she wrote it - she’d be glad to write more if this suits. He stands and extends his rough, large hand. She gives hi the manuscript.
(turning the pages over) Not a first attempt, I take it?
No, sir; she has sold to “Olympic” and “Scandal” and got a prize for a tale in the “Blarney Stone Banner.”
A prize?
(weakly) Yes.  He now takes in Jo’s appearance and her mended clothes.

Sit. Jo sits, hands folded, trying to cover the ink stains. Mr Dashwood reads her story with a pen in hand, gleefully crossing out and making notes, changes. Every time his pe scratches, Jo feels her heart breaking. She’s on the verg tears when:
We'll take this.
(looking up) You will?
With alterations. It’s too long. She nods and he hands it back to her, page after page wit her work crossed out. She examines it.
You’ve cut - I took care to have a few of my sinners repent.

The country just went through a war. People want to be amused, not preached at. Morals don’t sell nowadays. (pointedly) Perhaps mention that to your “friend.” Jo looks again at her completely altered story.
What do you - that is, what compensation —
We pay twenty-five to thirty for things of this sort. We’ll pay twenty for that.
(money over art) You can have it. Make the edits. Jo hands over the story, Mr. Dashwood hands over the mone business done.
(then) Should I tell my, my friend that you'll take another if she had one better than this?
We'll look at it. Tell her to make it short and spicy. And if the main character’s a girl make sure she’s married by the end. (casually) Or dead, either way.
Excuse me? But he’s on to the next bit of business.
What name would she like put to the story?
Oh, yes - none at all if you please. He considers her.
Just as she likes, of course.

Good morning, sir. Good day. EXT. NEW YORK CITY. DAY. CONTINUOUS. 1868. The streets of New York. After the Civil War and at the b of The Industrial Revolution. It is a city in the middle becoming, the 20th century on the horizon. Horses, trolle young, old, black, white, immigrants, returning soldiers, factory workers, wealthy industrialists, fashionable wome and poor mothers all crowd the streets. We find Jo (also becoming) sprinting down the street with utter joy. She has pulled up her skirts and is running fu steam. Not lady-running, flat-out RUNNING. For the joy of
Jo reading and walking at the same time, bounding two-at- time up the steps of a large brownstone boarding house. S stoops to pick up a cat who suns herself on the steps.

(to the cat) My Beth would like you very much. As Jo walks through the house, into the drawing room, she lets the cat down, and goes straight to the fireplace. Sh stands with her back to it, to warm herself, and produces small notebook and begins to write. She is so engrossed with her writing that she doesn’t hea the boisterous group of college students and professors, and a few women, when they descend upon the room. She jus keeps writing, until:

Good afternoon, Miss March. Jo looks up from her notebook to see FRIEDRICH BHAER look down at her. He speaks with a French accent, and, like al Europeans, seems to know something that we Americans don’
(she straightens up) Good afternoon, Professor.
You're on fire.
Thank you.

(suddenly animated) You're on fire! Jo suddenly notices that the back of her dress has caught fire. In a panic, another woman of the group helps her an the dress is put out. Disaster is avoided, although not humiliation.
(laughing) I have the same habit, you see?  5. He shows her scorch marks on his jacket. Jo is about to l when, MRS. KIRKE, the landlady, bustles into the room:
Kitty and Minny are waiting! Jo looks up the stairs to see the two little girls pranci
My students need me.
Always working.
(joke-dramatically) Money is the end and aim of my mercenary existence.
No one gets ink stains like yours just out of a desire for money. Jo feels the intense pleasure and pain of being seen by someone, of knowing that they know you.
(embarrassed, retreating) Well my sister Amy is in Paris, and until she marries someone obscenely wealthy, it’s up to me to keep the family afloat. Goodbye.

(staring up after her) Goodbye. EXT. FRANCE. PARIS. DAY. 1868. AMY MARCH, an angelic 20-year-old with golden curls, is painting a staged scene, along with a few other young artists. It is a classic scene of two young men and a you woman at a picnic, and Amy is rendering it realistically, imitating the 18th & 19th century painters she loved. She looks at the painting of the young man next to her. H doing something radically different - the paint is obviou the colors are bright and un-life-like, space is flattene It is not meant to be realistic: it is the beginning of modernism. She looks back at her own piece and realizes that she mig have missed the moment that she came here to master.  6. Perhaps she’s already passed before her time. She continu working, troubled. EXT. PARIS PROMENADE. DAY. 1868. Amy rides in an open air carriage with AUNT MARCH, readin letter from home. Everyone in Paris is out. Aunt March is only happy when she’s complaining, and she’s in excellent form this morning. It is the place to see and be seen and March is doing both excellently.
The decadents have ruined Paris, if you ask me. These French women couldn’t lift a hairbrush. No response from Amy.
AMY! I said, “These French women couldn’t lift a hairbrush.”
Oh yes! Very true, Aunt March.
Don’t humor me, girl. What do they write, your troublemaking family?
Mother doesn’t say anything about Beth. I feel I should go back but they all say “stay.”
You can do nothing if you go back. The girl is sick, not lonely. Amy gives her a hard look.
And you shouldn't go home until you and Fred Vaughn are properly engaged. Amy blushes and puts the letter away.
Yes, and until I’ve completed all of my painting lessons, of course. Aunt March looks at her, momentarily confused.
What? Oh, yes, yes. Of course. Amy looks at all the passers-by. She sees a somber young tall and dark and looking down as he walks. Suddenly!

Abandoning her primness, she launches out of the carriage runs, nearly knocking people over. This is Theodore Laure LAURIE, a 26-year-old without a sense of direction, like 26-year-olds. They hug joyously and un-self-consciously:
AMY! You're so /grown up! /You wrote you'd come to the hotel!
I looked for you and couldn’t /You didn’t look hard enoug find /you anywhere!
Maybe I just didn’t recognize (making a face) you, you’ve become so /Please don’t. beaut/iful.
I thought you liked that sort of thing!
NO. Where’s your Grandfather?
Still in Germany. I’m on my (teasing him) own, traveling and /having /and drinking and gambling fun. and flirting...
Don’t tell your mother!
Are you chasing some young girl across Europe?
(darkening) No.
(dropping her playfulness) I’m... I couldn’t believe Jo turned you down. I’m so sorry.
(crisp) Don’t be, Amy. I’m not.
(to Laurie) Oh, Aunt March! Laurie gallops over, and jumps into the carriage, kissing her:
Aren’t we fine, /Ma’am. /GET HIM OFF OF ME! He kisses her again, grinning.
Il faut GO! Allons-y! Aunt March attempts to get the carriage to leave, and Lau is thrown off while Amy is thrown in.

(calling after Laurie) Come to the New Year’s Party! It’s a ball and everyone will be there, including Fred - Pick me up at the hotel at eight - the Chavain! Dress for festivities! Top hats and silks!
I will! I’11 wear my best silk! Laurie turns and continues his heartbroken stroll, as Amy looks at him. She turns back to Aunt March.
It’s Laurie!

I know. Amy turns around to get one last look at Laurie. She love him, as she’s always loved him.  INT. TAILOR SHOP. AFTERNOON. 1868. MEG MARCH, beautiful but with the melancholy of yearning emanating from her, is browsing the silks with Sallie Mof a rich young woman who possesses an air of casual boredom that comes from never having to work for what you have.
(to the clerk) Twenty yards of the blue silk as well as the pink. Someone will be by for it later. She looks over at Meg, who touches a beautiful grey silk:
Oh Meg! That would look so lovely on you. I know just the dressmaker to send you to. You'll be the prettiest wife in Concord.
Oh no, John needs a new coat for winter and Daisy and Demi need new clothes and --
-- and his wife needs a new dress.
(trying to hide her embarrassment) I can’t... it’s, I just can’t.
He'll be so pleased with how you look that he’1ll forget all about the expense.
(equivocating) I don’t suppose it’s such an extravagance.
Will twenty yards do?

(deciding) Yes. Thank you. And Meg watches, delighted but fighting guilt, as the beautiful fabric is cut.  10. EXT. MEG MARCH’S HOUSE. DAY. 1868. From inside a modest rural cottage, Meg emerges, wiping h hands and muttering to herself.

(ashamed) Fifty dollars, what was I thinking? She sees her two 3-year-olds, a boy and a girl, DAISY and DEMI, playing in the yard. She sits down to watch them, feeling both grateful and trapped. They run up to her.

Mommy -- mommy! They fall into her arms, she accepts them and then sends off to play again. We hear sounds a beautiful Bach piano sonata being played... EXT. / INT. MARCH HOUSE. 1868. «+. the music grows louder as we see empty rooms of the childhood home -- the attic, the dining room, the stairs. Finally we find BETH MARCH, alone at the piano. She stops playing suddenly, as if in pain. Then she takes a deep breath, feels the sunlight on her hand, and stretches it

Beth! Beth? She doesn’t respond. INT. NEW YORK THEATRE. EVENING. 1868. Shakespeare’s Twelfth Night unfolds on stage. Jo is in th back, the cheap standing-room. She’s so wrapped up that s moves in until she’s practically leaning over the railing It’s the scene where Viola (dressed as a man) seduces Oli
.+-That you do think you are not what you are.

Then think you right, I am not what I am! Friedrich watches the play from his own, proper, seat. At certain point, he sees Jo, and then watches her watching play, her delight making him smile.  11. INT. NEW YORK THEATRE LOBBY. NIGHT. 1868. The audience flows out of the theatre into the lobby. Jo, still in her theatrical reverie, spots Friedrich. She freezes, not moving, not wanting to be seen. She then follows behind the band of friends, drawn to the spite of herself. INT. GERMAN BEER HALL. NIGHT. 1868. It is a rowdy and raucous crowd, drinking and dancing. Jo walks through the crowd, taking it in, watching Friedrich knows everyone and can speak half a dozen languages. Anot man young, speaking a language Jo doesn’t know, offers hi hand for the dance.
I’m sorry, I only speak English...

Come dance! He pulls her into the dance, and she does her best to fol along. It’s whirling and loud and wild. Before long, she finds herself paired with Friedrich and all self- consciousness leaves her. She is part of the night and th room and the music and she throws herself into movement, we are taken back to.... THE PAST. INT. CONCORD. MARCH HOUSE. JO & MEG’S ROOM. 186 ...the sisters, all together again in the past, in the sn globe of girlhood and memory that is ever present but for gone, are in a flurry of getting ready for a holiday part
I know just who I’1l1 dance with!
Who will you dance with, Jo?
You know I never dance.
I can’t dance.
Why can’t we all go to the party?! It’s not fair! Meg's hair is covered in papers, and Jo manipulates a pai hot tongs. Meg struggles to get on a pair of slippers.  12.
Just wear your regular (forcing it) /shoes. /These fit last winter! Amy puts on jewels and rouge and tries to shape her nose.
My nose will simply not look refined.
(to no-one) I like your nose.
(reaching to Jo) Now, Jo --
-- don’t touch me, thanks! I already feel ridiculous I don’t want to look it!
You could be pretty if you tried.
Don't want to, won’t do it.
I don’t want to go but I wish I could hear all the music.
I'll keep it all in my head and try to sing it for you when I get home. Jo goes back to working on Meg’s hair. Beth watches Jo ha the tongs, amazed and slightly worried:
Ought they to smoke /like (confident) that? /It's the dampness drying.
What a queer smell - it’s like... burnt feathers.
There, now you'll see a perfect little ringlet.  13. Jo removes the tongs, and a burnt clump of hair follows. screams and Meg screams because Jo screams.
(gasps, half delighted) /Why is her hair off? You're /ruined!
Meg, I’m so sorry!

(looking in the mirror) /I'm sorry! You shouldn't What have you done?! /Marmee have asked me to do it! I I’m spoilt! I can’t go! My ruin everything! hair! INT. GARDINER'S NEW YEAR’S PARTY. HALLWAY. NIGHT. 1861. Meg and Jo walk down the hallway at the Gardiner’s very f party, the party already in full swing. Meg is chastising
Don’t stare, don’t put your hands behind your back, don’t say Christopher Columbus, don’t say Capital, don’t shake hands, don’t whistle -- Meg is immediately pulled away.
Meg March! You look so pretty! Sallie Moffat, at that moment Sallie Gardiner, pulls Meg from Jo, who is left standing awkwardly.

Meg... Meg seems to put on another face and attitude, more grown and elegant. Jo fades away into the back of the party. INT. GARDINER’S NEW YEAR’S PARTY. CONCORD. NIGHT. 1861. Jo, 16, miserable, glumly watches the dancers. She pulls string on her dress. She catches Meg’s eyes, 17, laughing with her dance partner, and pleads with her to leave. Meg aggressively shakes her head, and Jo sighs, resigned. A very large red-headed boy makes a beeline for Jo - in h terror, she looks for an escape.  She slips behind sits on Theodore 17-year-old boy.
a curtain, and walking backwards, she nearly Laurence (!), Laurie, a very serious looking
Dear me, I didn’t know any (rising) one /was here! /Don’t mind me; stay, if you like.
I won’t disturb you?
Not at all; I don’t know many people, and felt rather strange at first, you know.
So do I. They stand there, unsure of what to do, both shy.
Miss March, isn’t it?
Yes, Mr. Laurence, but I’m not Miss March, I’m only Jo.
And I’m not Mr. Laurence, I’m only Laurie. Their first burst of conversation has run it’s course, an they smile at each other, standing in the not-unpleasant awkwardness of meeting.
Don’t you dance? I don’ yet -
t know how you do things here you see, I’ve spent most of my life in Europe.
EUROPE! That’s CAPITAL! (she catches herself) I shouldn’t use words like that.
Says who?  15.
Meg. She's my older sister. They peek through the curtain and watch Meg dance.
That’s her, see? The girl (looking) in the violet /dress? /Very pretty.
She reminds me to be good so Father will be proud of me when he returns.
Where is he?
Volunteered for the Union Army. I wanted to go fight with him. I can’t get over my disappointment in being a girl. Laurie doesn’t look disappointed that she’s a girl at all
Jo ... would you like to dance? With me?
I can’t, because...
Because what?
You won’t tell?
Never!
I scorched my dress, see? Meg told me to keep still, so no one would see it. You can laugh if you want to. It’s funny, I know. Laurie does not laugh, but looks quite tender.

Never mind that; I’11 tell you how we can manage.  16. EXT. GARDINER’S NEW YEAR'S PARTY. PORCH. NIGHT. 1861. Laurie bows, Jo awkwardly curtsies and then they go danci wildly up and down a wrap-around porch. It’s actually ver romantic in its exuberance. Sometimes Jo is the woman and sometimes the man - same with Laurie. They are mid-spin w they see Meg wildly gesture at them from inside: She’s hu
My foot- I’ve hurt my ankle. INT. GARDINER’S NEW YEAR’S PARTY. HALLWAY. NIGHT. 1861. Meg limps, Jo supports her and Laurie trails behind.
How will I get home?!
I don’t see what you can do /Carriages are too expensive. except get a carriage or stay /here all night.
Well, let me take you. It’s right next door.
No, thank you, we cannot accept.
You must take mine. Please!
No, it’s so early -- you can’t mean to leave yet.
I always leave early - I do, truly.
What choice do you have? INT./EXT. MARCH HOUSE. NIGHT. 1861. A laughing Marmee, holding a book and covered in flour, o the door on Laurie and Jo, supporting Meg.

(laughing) Goodness gracious, what have you done!  17. Marmee has none of the pretensions of the other mothers, artifice. She’s a hippie before they existed. The little girls, Amy and Beth come rushing down the stai and attack the older girls.
Here, make room, /Meg is a /I sprained my ankle dancing! wounded soldier!
Oh Meg - You’1l kill yourself for fashion one of these days. Hannah! We need ice!

Tell us about it!/ (to Jo) (re: Laurie) /Was the music wonderful? What’s he like? Laurie stands apart, not wanting to be a disruption, but loving the March household, this slightly medieval utopia artists and thinkers.
Come in come in! Apologies for the chaos: I enjoy baking in the middle of the night! Don’t mind the clutter, Mr. Laurence, we don’t.
Laurie, please.
(calling over) Can I call you Teddy?!
Yes!
You must be part of the girls’ theatricals!
(pointedly) I'm Amy.
Hello.  18.

They could use an extra player, although you’ll have to fight Jo for the male roles or play a girl. Here, have a scone. Marmee hands him the scone, as Hannah enters with ice for Meg's ankle. Amy keeps sneaking looks at Laurie.
(cracking herself up) Laurie, how are your ankles? Do you need ice?
(laughing) No, thank you, ma’am. Instantly, she sees his loneliness, his lack of a mother.
Oh, just call me Mother, or Marmee. Everyone does. He doesn’t say anything, but looks as if he’s about to cr He doesn’t have a mother, and hasn’t had one for a long t

It really seems like being a /I don’t believe fine young fine young lady to come home ladies enjoy themselves a bi from my party in a carriage more than we do. and have maids to /wait on me! The girls laugh and prance and gossip around the warm fir He stands apart, loving them all, the whole family... EXT. MARCH HOUSE. NIGHT. CONTINUOUS. .--but most especially Jo. As Laurie retreats back to his big, lonely house, he looks across the field to Jo, writi alone in the attic, absorbed with her work.

head_text.subj: THE PRESENT. EXT./INT. NEW YORK BOARDING HOUSE. NIGHT. 18

text: Jo works with her writing costume on: an antique military jacket. Her writing is like an attack, moving into enemy territory and occupying space. Her hand starts to cramp, shakes it, stretches it, and then switches hands. Suddenly she stops - she’s heard something. She opens the door, but the hallway is empty. She looks down and sees a book, a very beautiful copy of The Complete Works of Will Shakespeare. She opens the cover - inside there is a note  19.

(read to camera) For the writer in the attic: Because you enjoyed the play so much tonight, I wanted you to have this. It will help you study character and paint it with your pen. I would love to read what you're writing, if you’ll trust me. I promise honesty and whatever intelligence I can muster. Yours, Friedrich Jo opens the book and almost greedily she begins to read, reciting the words to herself. INT. PARIS. BALLROOM. 1868. A gorgeous Paris ball, and Amy is lively and everyone's favorite at the party. She dances with Fred Vaughn most often, gossips with his sister and her friends, and is charming to everyone. Suddenly, Amy sees something that makes her look sour, an follow her gaze to see Laurie entering: He is loud, drunk has two girls with him. They all fall into a sofa, laughi and loud. Amy frowns and approaches. She stands before him, annoyed
Laurie.
(bleary, looking up) Amy.
I waited an hour for you.
I feel caught. Laurie clumsily makes a space for her while the other lad depart. Amy does not, and walks away, forcing him to foll
Amy, please!
Do you want to know what I honestly think of you?  20.
What do you honestly think of me?
I despise you.
(almost laughing) Why do you despise me?
Because with every chance for /Oh this is interesting. being good, useful and happy, you are faulty, lazy and /miserable.
Selfish people do like to talk about themselves.
Am I selfish?
Yes, very selfish. With your /Beauty? money, talent, beauty and /health --

- ah you like that, you old vanity - with all these good things to enjoy, you can find nothing to do but dawdle. He drunkenly puts his hand over hers. He wears a ring on pinky finger, which he never takes off:
(making fun of her) I‘1l be good for you, Saint Amy, I’1l be good!
Aren’t you ashamed of a hand like that?
No, I’m not.  21.
It looks like it’s never done a day of work in its life. And that ring is ridiculous.
Jo gave me this ring. Amy considers him seriously.
I feel sorry for you, I really do. I just wish you'd bear it better.
You don’t have to feel sorry for me, Amy. You'll feel the same way one day.
(with significance) No, I'd be respected if I couldn't be loved.

(drunken meanness) And what work have you done lately, oh great “artiste” - or have you been too busy imagining how you’1l spend Fred Vaughn’s fortune? FRED VAUGHN, ladies and gentlemen! Amy smarts, his comment cut her to the core. Laurie takes very messy leave and she looks to Fred --

Fred, I’m, I’m so sorry. INT. BOARDING HOUSE DRAWING ROOM. NYC. DAY. 1868. Friedrich holds a few newspaper clippings and handwritten pages. Jo paces and watches him read, nervous. He laughs, smiles at his laughter. He finishes reading, puts down the work, and looks at her instantly feels that she needs to explain.
Those are just stories, of course, but I’m working on a novel.
And your novel, it will be like this?  22.
Yes... so far /anyway. /With plots like this, duels and killing?
It sells.
Why don’t you sign your real name?
My mother wouldn’t like it, it’s too, gory for her.
Yes?
(explaining) I want to help with the money I make and not worry her. He considers, then speaks:
I don’t like them.
Honestly, I think that they’re not good.
(fumbling) But, I, they’re published in the papers, and, people have always said - I’m considered talented -
Oh I think you’re talented, which is why I’m being so blunt. Jo, deeply offended, starts to gather up her work.
I can’t afford to starve on praise.
Are you upset?  23.
Of course I’m upset! You just told me you didn’t like my work!
I thought you wanted honesty.
(stuck) I... do.
Has no one ever talked to you like this before?
I've been rejected plenty of times.
But do you have anyone to /And who made you High Priest take you seriously, to talk of what’s good and what’s about your/work? bad?
No one, and I’m not.
Then why are you acting like it?
Your reaction indicates that /My reaction indicates that you must think there is some you are a pompous blowhard. truth /in it. Shakespeare wrote for the masses.
He was the greatest poet who ever lived. He smuggled his poetry in popular works.
I’m no Shakespeare.
Thank goodness, we already have him.
If you know so much about it, why don’t you do it yourself?  24.

I’m not a writer. I don’t have the gifts you have. She does what she does when she’s hurt, which is that she gets incredibly mean instantaneously, without meaning to, without being able to take it back.
No, you don’t, and you’1l (amused) always be a critic, never an /I'm sure they will. author, and the world will forget that you ever even lived /but no one..
But, I’1l be, but...
Yes?
(not sure of herself) No one will forget Jo March.
I can believe it. An energy between them and then she kills it definitively

We are not friends, you are not my friend. And I don’t want your opinion because I don’t like you very much so just don’t talk to me anymore, thank you. She turns to leave, hiding all the emotions. EXT. NEW YORK CITY. TWILIGHT INTO NIGHT. 1868. Jo, in fury and confusion, walks the streets, letting her feelings burn out. She strides through the entire night t way, like Charles Dickens’ Night Walks. INT. BOARDING HOUSE. DAY. 1869. After her walk -- Mrs. Kirke hands Jo a telegram:
Josephine, this came for you. Jo tears it open and quickly reads.  25.
Dear Jo, Our Beth has taken a turn for the worse. Please, come home as soon as you can.

(breathes, crumpling the note) Beth. INT. TRAIN. DAY. 1869. Jo drifts off to sleep, lulled by the movement. The count speeds past her. As she goes forward towards her childhoo home that is now no longer her home, and to the past that can no longer find... THE PAST. INT. ATTIC OF THE MARCH HOUSE. MORNING. 1861. Jo March is sleeping in her large, cozy writing chair, a blanket wrapped around her. Her fingers are stained with and pages are strewn about her. Sounds of the day start t drift upstairs to her perch. Her eyes flutter open at the distant sound of...
Jo! Jo! Where /are you? /Do you like these garlands?
They're beautiful! Jo yawns and stretches and looks through the attic window onto the snow-covered New England world:

(whispered to herself) Merry Christmas, world. She wraps the blanket around her and quietly opens the at door and sneaks down, watching her sisters, her heart's j fussing over the decorations Amy has made.
(calling out) Merry Christmas! They all look up, delighted:
Jo! We've been up /for hours! /What have you been writing Jo clomps down the stairs, pages of the play in her hand.
I got carried away with our delicious revenge play last night.
No, no poison it’s /Christmas.
It’s so dreadful to be /poor.
At least we have father and mother and /each other.
(flopping down) /Christmas won't be Christmas without any presents.
(injured) /I don't think it’s fair for some girls to have lots of pretty things and other girls nothing at all.
(glum) /We haven't got father. And we won’t have him for as long as this war drags on. (putting down her sewing) I wish I had heaps of money and plenty of servants, need to work again.
so I’d never You could be a proper actress on the boards!
(privately delighted) I can’t be an /actress.
(prancing)
/They aren’t all fallen women. I have lots of wishes, but my favorite one is to be an artist and go to Paris and do fine pictures and be the best painter in the
world.
(cuddling up to Jo) That’s what you want too, isn’t it Jo? To be a famous writer?  27.
Yes, but it sounds so crass when she says it.
Why be ashamed of what you /I'm not! /want?
My wish is to have us all to be together with Father and Mother in this house - that’s what I want.
(under her breath) /SHHHHHH. Beth is /perfect.
What about your music, Queen Bess?
(blushing) I only do that for us, I don’t need anyone else to hear it.
(trying to shape her nose) You must not limit yourself.
(standing, ending it) Mother proposed not having any presents this Christmas because our men are suffering in the army. We can’t do much, but we should make our little sacrifices and do it gladly.
Don’t play mother just because she’s not home. Jo throws a pillow at Meg, it hits her squarely in the fa
Don’t Jo; it’s so boyish.
That’s why I /do it. (disdainfully) /I detest rude, unlady-like girls.
I hate affected little chits!  28. Jo tackles Amy and Beth and pulls in Meg. They commence p fighting. In the tussle, Amy shouts out:
Watch my nose! My nose! It’s already no good!

(entering) I know you don’t care what I think, but you don’t want your mother to find you like this, do you? The girls untangle and run to Hannah. She’s a good-nature woman old enough to be their grandmother.
(kissing her) /You're more family than Of course we care what /you wicked old Aunt March. think.
Don't, /Jo. /Where is Marmee?
Goodness only knows. Some poor creature came a-beggin', and your ma went straight off to see what was needed.
I wish she could help other people at a time convenient to us.
(holding her doll) Joanna and I are very hungry.
Dolls don’t get hungry, Beth.
(holing up the pages) I've re-written the climax and we need to set it to memory. Amy, get the costumes.

Hurry! I’1l be late! They break apart from each other at the fork in the road, Beth and Meg going one direction and Amy and Jo in anothe EXT. AUNT MARCH'S HOUSE. THE SAME DAY. 1862. She's upstairs. Oh, my Jo. We all thought she was better but the fever had weakened her heart. Jo produces an envelope full of money.
Take this and find her the best doctor you can.

(shaking her head) I’m not going back. I’m using the rest to take her to the sea and get her strong. She hugs all the women again.
When is Amy coming home? Marmee and Meg exchange glances.

Jo, don’t be angry with your sister...  49. THE PAST. INT. MARCH HOUSE. EVENING. 1862. Jo, in her and Meg's room, places a pretty cover page on of the novel she has written. She lovingly writes “For Father,” and hears:

I’ve been shut up in here and I never get to go anywhere. Beth has her piano but I’m so lonely!
(from the piano) I can teach you chords.

Has anyone taken my novel?

It isn’t! I haven’t got it - I don’t know where it is and I don’t care.
Tell me or /I’'1l make you! (trying to hold her back) /Jo, don't! (calling)
BOOK! I TOLD YOU I’D MAKE YOU PAY
You wicked girl! You wicked, wicked girl! I can never write it again! I'll never forgive you as long as I live!

They are fighting, full-out fighting, during these last lines, as their sisters and Marmee attempt to stop it. INT. JO’S ROOM. EVENING. 1862. Jo is weeping, Beth cradling her head, Meg holds her hand Marmee enters with Amy, who looks penitent. Marmee nods a her, as if to say “go ahead”:

Amy...

I am the most sorry for it now. I’m so sorry. Marmee approaches the bed.
Don’t let the sun go down on your anger. Forgive her. Help each other, and you begin again tomorrow.

(running from the room) She doesn’t deserve my forgiveness. I will hate her! I will hate her forever! INT. MARCH HOUSE. KITCHEN. MORNING. 1862. A very tense breakfast: Jo’s eyes are red and puffy and a remorseful Amy tries to sit beside her and make peace, bu changes seats away from her. Amy looks pleadingly at Meg. Laurie bursts open the back door, unaware of all the trou
Good morning ladies! It’s brisk and brilliant and I think the last day for the river - get your ice skates! Jo springs up, thrilled to have something to do.
One second! Go down, and I’11 /I want to come too! Last /be right there! time you promised I could go! Jo, not acknowledging her, grabs her skates and races out  54.
(wailing) Is she going to be like this forever?!
It was a very hard loss /for /Is there nothing I can do? her.

(conspiratorially) Go after her. Don't say anything till Jo has got good-natured with Laurie, then take a quiet minute and just kiss her, or do some kind thing, and I'm sure she'll be friends again. Heartened, Amy grabs her skates. EXT. RIVER. DAY. 1862. Amy runs out of the house, calling:

My sister, my sister, dear God thank you for my sweet sister.  56. INT. MARCH HOUSE. AMY AND BETH’S ROOM. EVENING. 1862. Amy is asleep, covered in blankets. Jo is slumped down on floor beside her, not even feeling herself worthy of a ch Marmee adjusts Amy’s blanket, and then looking at Jo, dec to take a seat beside her, on the floor:
She’s asleep.
If she had died it would've been my fault.

What is wrong with me? I’ve made so many resolutions and written sad notes and cried over my sins but it doesn’t seem to help. When I get in a passion I get so savage, I could hurt anyone and enjoy it.

I’ve just told Fred Vaughn that I wouldn't marry him. INT. MARCH HOUSE. BETH’S ROOM. DAY. 1869. Meg is watching over Beth, who is getting weaker by the d Jo comes up with a bowl of soup, and touches Meg on the shoulder, relieving her.
Meg. Jo cocks her head towards the window, John is standing outside. EXT. MARCH HOUSE. GARDEN. DAY. 1869. Meg and John are talking, tentative after their quarrel.
I’1l come home to help with /Stay. I asked for leave. the children, I’m sorry, I’m I’1l take care of the just so worried /for Beth. children.
(embracing him) John.  88.
And there’s another thing - you should send your fabric to the dressmaker as soon as possible.
But I /can’t -- /No, don't say another word, I won’t hear it. I want you to have that dress. My old coat will be fine for the winter.
But /John, it’s -- It’s all settled.
No, John, I really can’t. I sold the fabric to Sallie.
You did?
Yes.
I don’t want you to be unhappy.

I couldn't be, John Brooke is my husband and I am his wife. Meg kisses him, spontaneously, just like years earlier. INT. MARCH HOUSE. BETH’S ROOM. DAY. 1869. From the window, Jo watches the loving scene - feeling ha for her sister and also a pang of loneliness. Suddenly, a crash - the soup bowl clatters to the floor. Beth's fever is high and she knocked everything off the b Jo flies to her side, feeling her forehead, calling.
Hannah! THE PAST. INT. BETH’S ROOM. DAY. 1862. Just as in the present, Beth has gotten worse.
What do we do?  89.

We should send for your mother. THE PRESENT. INT. BETH’S ROOM. EVENING. 1869. Jo lays in bed with Beth. THE PAST. INT. BETH’S ROOM. EVENING. 1862. Marmee enters with Laurie and goes straight to Beth. She’ gone from a sick husband to a sick daughter, but she brin cheerful efficiency to a terrifying situation.
You were right to send for me, my girls - but you’ve been very good nurses indeed.
It’s mostly been Jo, she’s hardly slept.
I didn’t know what else to do.
Hannah, go make a clear broth and Jo get ice - we need to cool her.
Who is with Father?
John is staying with him. Meg smiles to herself, which her Mother notices.

(looking at the bed) We need to change the linens. Marmee attends to Beth while the girls help her. THE PRESENT. INT. BETH’S ROOM. NIGHT. 1869. Meg and Jo and Marmee take turns in shifts, making sure t Beth is as comfortable as she can be. When it is Jo’s tur Beth is very weak, barely able to hold her head up.
(whispering to Beth) Don’t go quietly, fight!  90.

Please fight to the end, be LOUD! Don’t just quietly go away! Jo is sitting watch, and drops off to sleep, her head on bed, her hand grasping Beth’s. Beth opens her eyes and lo down at Jo and smiles. She closes her eyes again and drif away. THE PAST. INT. BETH’S ROOM. EVENING. 1862. Jo jerks suddenly awake - she doesn’t see Beth in the bed She rises, and with growing panic - screams.
Marmee! Marmee! She rushes downstairs to find Beth sitting up with her Mo and Hannah eating. She cries with joy, and kisses Beth’s head.

Merry Christmas, Beth. INT. MARCH HOUSE. LIVING ROOM. AFTEROON. 1862. It is Christmas time again. Amy, standing on a chair, supervises all the decorations. Mr. Laurence and Marmee s by the fire, and Beth on the couch with her doll. Jo runs around with Hannah setting the table for their feast. At just that moment, Laurie pops his head in and with wil excitement in his eyes, announces:

And here’s another Christmas gift for the March family! The door swings open, and it’s Father, supported by Mr. Brooke. Mayhem breaks out - Beth starts crying, Amy falls a chair, Marmee gasps, Jo drops a dish, and Meg (again) spontaneously kisses Mr. Brooke. All the girls run to him surrounding him in a hug.

(joyfully overwhelmed) My little women. How you've grown, and how proud I am of you. Each of you. Merry Christmas, my dears. He looks over them to Marmee - who is gazing back at him love. She wasn’t sure that this moment would come for her and she can hardly believe she has her family together. H steps out of his daughters’ hug to embrace his wife.  91.

(crying out of happiness) Thank god, thank god you’re home. Now I can be angry with you in person. He laughs, and brushes her tears away. It is romance, but real kind. LATER: It is Christmas dinner, with everyone, including t Laurences and Mr. Brooke, gathered around the table - it the finest day any one of them has ever had, and the joy radiates across the chilly Christmas night. THE PRESENT. INT. BETH’S ROOM. MORNING. 1869. Jo jerks awake to find Beth gone - she goes downstairs an sees Marmee there. Jo looks at Marmee, and her mother, fo the first time in Jo's life, breaks. Jo becomes the paren that moment, comforting her mother, who is trapped in the unimaginable pain of losing a child. EXT. GRAVEYARD. DAY. 1869. The March family: Mother and Father and Jo, Meg and John their arms around each other, and Hannah. They have all gathered to lay their Beth to rest on an impossibly beaut day. The party walks away, each with their own pain. Jo stays, unable to leave Beth’s side, even in death. Meg makes to go approach her - but John pulls Meg closer. Meg nods - and she is grateful to him, grateful that she married this man who can be there for her. Jo cries, alone. She cannot comprehend how the world keep spinning when her Beth is gone. We go from the emptiness the grief to... THE PAST. EXT./INT. MARCH HOUSE. MEG & JO’S ROOM. SPRING. DAY. 1865. .+-a beautiful day, full of flowers and sunlight. Outside Beth and Amy are arranging decorations and laughing. Inside, Meg prepares for her wedding with Jo helping her, placing flowers in her sister’s hair.
I can’t believe today is my wedding day!  92.
(sadly) Me neither.
What’s wrong?
Nothing.
Jo suddenly kneels before her, wild and desperate: But, Jo..
We can leave. We can leave right now.
What?
I can make money: I’1l1 sell stories, I'll do anything - cook, clean, work in a factory. I can make a life for us.
And you, you should be an actress and have a life on the stage. Let’s run away together.
I want to get married.
I love him.
(angry) You will be bored of him in two years and we will be interesting forever.
Just because my dreams are not the same as yours doesn’t mean they’re unimportant.  93. Jo sits back, heartbroken.
I want a family and a home and I’m not scared of working and struggling, but I want to do it with John.
I just hate that you’re leaving me.
Oh, Jo, I’m not leaving you. Besides, one day it will be your turn.
I'd rather be a free spinster and paddle my own canoe. (hugging her, crying) I can’t believe childhood is over.
It was going to end one way or another. And what a happy end. EXT. MARCH HOUSE. GARDEN. DAY. 1865. Meg and Mr. Brooke are married, with Mr. March officiatin

What excessive promises, giving yourself away to get the other. What a thing, what a gift, always given before it is known the cost or the reward. During the simple and emotional ceremony, Amy and Jo catc each others eye - they simultaneously realize that they a the only two left standing. Later, during the picnic reception: - Marmee and Hannah deliver cakes and pastries and food galore. - Laurie dances with Beth, whirling her around, and makin her laugh. Jo watches adoringly: the two halves of her he - Meg, both bride and host, makes sure everyone is cared - Laurie and Jo taste the alcohol and decide it’s terribl

- Meg dances with John, Marmee dances with Mr. Laurence, tries to play the fiddle - then Marmee dances with Father and Meg dance, John and Amy dance, Hannah dances with Fat The point is, everyone dances with everyone and... - Mr. Laurence offers to dance with Aunt March, but she t him down. Then Laurie also approaches her. Aunt March fei even MORE hatred, to cover her epic delight. - There is more eating and dancing until the sun starts t set. As Aunt March moves to make her departure, she speak Meg, who stands with John, Marmee and Father March.

Well, I hope you’re happy. Now that you've ruined your life, just like your Mother did by marrying your father. Despite her meanness, the March family is so happy, that burst out laughing at Aunt March’s rudeness.
Dear Sister, you are too kind. And thank you for today’s festivities.
You are most welcome.
(leaning in to kiss her) Thank you Aunt March.
Oh, oh, I don’t like to be...
Oh, I’m sorry.
(back at Meg) You'll be sorry when you've tried love in a cottage and found it a failure!
(smiling sweetly) It can’t be worse than some people find in big houses.
I understood your meaning, my dear.  95. Meg and John retreat and laugh and kiss. Nothing can pier their happiness.
(to Marmee) I don’t miss a THING.
(taking Aunt March’s arm and leading her away) You are not entirely wrong.
I may not always be right, but I am NEVER wrong. Amy takes over from Marmee, Aunt March gratefully accepti her hand.

Thank goodness, here’s the only sane member of the family. I really can’t take any more of this. Amy leads her away, and Marmee lets them go. Amy gets Aun March into a carriage and then lets out a cry of joy. She runs to Marmee, who is now standing with Jo:
Marmee! Marmee! Aunt March is /wants me to go with her! H going to Europe /and wonderful! Now I know why I spent all those BORING hours reading to her! Jo throws her arms around Amy, delighted.
No, she... she wanted me to come. As her companion.
(stunned) Europe? With you?
She wants me to work on my art, and my French, of course.

Oh... I, that’s wonderful Amy. Marmee takes Jo’s hand, knowing how this hurt her. Jo smi through her pain for Meg’s day, but it is a true blow.  96. INT. MEG’S HOUSE. DAY. 1865. John and Meg enter their small but lovely newlywed home. embraces her and kisses her - she’s never been happier. EXT. WOODS. DAY. CONTINUOUS. 1866. Laurie and Jo walk through the woods together, as they've done for years.
Meg married, Amy off to Europe, now that you’re a graduate, you’1ll be off on a long holiday - I’m not good like Beth so I’m angry and restless.
You don’t have to stay here.
Why? Should we run off and join a pirate ship? He looks at her, and inhales, about to talk. Jo sees his and immediately knows what is about to happen. No, no,
(panicking) No, Teddy -- please don’t.
It’s no use Jo; we’ve got to have it out..

/we don't... I’ve loved you ever since I’ve known you Jo -- I couldn’t help it, and you’ve been so good to me -- I’ve tried to show it but you wouldn’t let me; now I’m going to make you hear and give me an answer because I can’t go on like this any longer.  97.

I wanted to save you from (not listening to her) this, I thought /you’d /I've worked hard to please understand. you, and I gave up billiards and everything you didn’t like, and waited and never complained for I hoped you'd love me, though I’m not half good enough --
Yes, you are, you’re a great deal too good for me, and I’m so grateful to you and so proud of you, I don’t see why I... I can’t love you as you want me to.
You can’t?
(helplessly) I can’t change the feeling and it would be a lie to say I do when I don’t. I’m so sorry, Teddy, so desperately sorry, but I can’t help it... Laurie backs away from her like she hit him.
I can’t love any one else.
It would be a disaster if we married, we'd be miserable! We both have such quick tempers --
-- If you loved me Jo, I would be a perfect saint!
I can’t - I’ve tried it and failed.
Everyone expects it -- Grandpa and your family, Jo say you will and let’s be happy!
I can’t say “Yes” truly so I won’t say it at all.  98.
You'll see that I’m right, eventually, and you’1ll thank me for it.
I‘1l be hanged if I do!

You'll find some lovely accomplished girl, who will adore you, and make a fine mistress for your fine house. I wouldn’t. I’m homely and awkward and odd and you'd be ashamed of me and we would quarrel - we can’t help it even now! - I’d hate elegant society and you'd hate my scribbling and we would be unhappy and wish we hadn’t done it and everything will be horrid.
Anything more?
Nothing more -- except that... (honest) I don’t believe I will ever marry. I’m happy as I am, and love my liberty too well to be in any hurry to give it up.
(shaking his head) You will care for somebody, and you'll love him tremendously, and live and die for him. I know you will, it’s your way, and you will and I’1ll watch.

Teddy. . He straightens up and walks away. Jo cries and cries. Her heart is breaking, even though she is the one who broke i THE PRESENT. INT. MARCH HOUSE. ATTIC. DAY. 1869. Jo is putting away Beth’s things, and arranging her littl dolls and toys. Everyone is gone. Meg left by marriage, A left by a voyage to Europe, Laurie left because she rejec him and Beth was taken from this life. She places sheet m of Beth’s into a trunk, the hurt in her heart almost unbearable.  99.
I hope I’m not disturbing your writing...
I don’t do that anymore. (then) It didn’t save her. They sit beside each other, both missing Beth.
You are much too lonely here, Jo. Wouldn't you like to go back to New York? What about your friend - Friedrich, was that his name?
(resigned) I ruined our friendship with my temper, just as I ruin everything.
I doubt a sincere friend would be deterred.
I wish that were true. If I were a girl in a book, this would all be so easy, I’d give up the world happily.
Laurie is returning, you know.
(looking up) He is?
There was a letter from Amy, she’s coming home: She was devastated about Beth and Aunt March is very ill - but Laurie will be accompanying them on the journey home.
(nodding) That’s good of him. Jo stands and paces, anxiously.  100.
What is it?
Perhaps... perhaps I was too quick in turning him down.
Do you love him?
If he asked me again, I think I would say yes... Do you think he’1l ask me again?
But do you love him?
(tearing up) I know that I care more to be loved. I want to be loved.
That is not the same as loving.

(crying, trying to explain herself to herself) Women have minds and souls as well as hearts, ambition and talent as well as beauty and I’m sick of being told that love is all a woman is fit for. But... I am so lonely. EXT. PARIS. FRANCE. DAY. 1869. Amy, dressed in black, is waiting with all her luggage - is in mourning. A carriage approaches and Laurie gets out tentatively walks to Amy.
I couldn’t let you travel alone with Aunt March being so sick - even if you despise me.
Oh, Laurie, I don’t despise you. She embraces him, weeping.
Beth was the best of us.  101. Laurie is quiet, letting her cry. She pulls back.
I’m not marrying Fred Vaughn.
(carefully) I heard... Amy...

(rush of words) It was not for you it was for myself. You are under no obligation to say anything or do anything, it was because I didn’t love him as I should. Laurie studies her face, and we know that he sees her and loves her.

(still rambling) You don’t have to say anything, we never need to talk about it, we don’t have to talk about -- Laurie catches her face with his hands, and kisses her. S looks at him and kisses him back. They embrace with both their joy and their grief. This is the way it was meant. is done. INT. MARCH HOUSE ATTIC. DAY. 1869. Jo infused with a new kind of energy, writes to Laurie. W hear snippets of the letter.
My dear Teddy, I miss you more than I can express. EXT. MARCH HOUSE. DAY. 1869. In the forest, Jo finds the mailbox.

...I used to think the worst fate was to be a wife, I was young and stupid. Now I have changed. The worst fate is to live my life without you in it. I was wrong to turn you down and to run away to New York.  102. She opens it and places the letter inside, she looks at i satisfied. She closes the mailbox back up again. THE PAST. EXT. STREETS OF NEW YORK CITY. DAY. 1867. Jo tries to find her way through the unfamiliar city - sh isn’t an expert at it quite yet. She walks too slowly, st too long, and gets hopelessly lost - but a spark of happi is growing, she’s figuring out how to be what Aunt March was impossible - a woman making her own way in the world. She walks up the stairs to the boarding house and as she ascends the stairs and the doors open, we hear:

head_text.subj: THE PRESENT. INT./EXT. MARCH HOUSE. LIVING ROOM. DAY. 186

text: Jo, asleep on the couch, is gently shaken awake. She sees
Jo? Wake up!
Oh Teddy! My Teddy!
Dear Jo, are you glad to see me then? Jo embraces him and looks at him and holds him for too lo
Glad, my blessed boy, is too small! Words can’t express it. Laurie breaks their embrace.
Oh thank heaven, I was worried, well, anyway, I wanted a moment with you alone.
Yes, of course. Here, come sit. They take a moment, not sure what to do. They aren’t in t youth any longer, they aren’t sure how to relate to each other.
(making a joke) How's Amy?  103.
Did she bother you all the way from Europe with her preening?
(laughs ) Yes, but I love it.
Where is she now? Did she not come straight home?
Your mother’s got her down at Meg's, we stopped there by the way, and there was no getting my wife out of their clutches.
Your... your what?
Now I’ve done it! It was meant to be a surprise.
What surprise?
Well, we were engaged, and we were going to wait... that is to say, now we are man and wife. Jo sits. She’s hit hard.
You and... Amy.
It all happened very fast.
Are you - in love?

Yes. (launching in) Jo, I want to say one thing, and then we’ll put it away forever. I have always loved you; but the love I feel for Amy is different - you were right - we would have killed each other.  104.
(still in shock) Yes.
I think it was meant this way.
Oh, Teddy.
No one ever calls me that but you.
What does Amy call you?
My Lord.
That’s like her... Well, you look deserving of it.
Can we - can we still be friends? Though it takes a supreme effort, she says:

Of course, my boy, always. At that moment, everyone comes bursting through the door. Mother and Father and Amy and John and Meg and Daisy and - Amy goes straight to Jo. Jo fixes her face and decides will be the person she wishes she was:
Laurie told you?
Yes. Amy looks at her expectantly. Jo has a moment of wanting strike her, the way she did when they were children, but checks herself, and tries to be what Beth would want:
Amy, I’m so happy for you. It was meant to be. Amy sighs, her anxiety lifts:  105.
Oh, I’m so relieved - I couldn't write because it all happened so quickly and then, really, I was worried you'd be angry.
(shaking her head) No, no.
So you aren’t? Angry?
Life is too short to be angry at one’s sisters.
(tearing up) I really miss her...

I know. They embrace. Over her shoulder she catches her mother’s who gives her a look of infinite empathy. Then Laurie calls for his wife. Jo straightens up and see these couples - Mother & Father, John & Meg, Laurie & Amy It all hits her with a heat and a mass that she was unprepared for. She hastily excuses herself and goes outs EXT. MARCH HOUSE. DAY. 1869. Weeping, but also in a panic, Jo removes the letter from mailbox and walks into the woods. EXT. WOODS. DAY. 1869. She tears through the woods and finally stands by the riv breathing heavily. For one moment, we believe that she mi end her suffering in the most tragic way - she leans towa the river... .--and throws the letter into it, letting it drift away, along with her childhood love. It is over. EXT. MARCH HOUSE. DAY. 1869. Jo trudges back, and is surprised to find Mr. Laurence standing alone, looking at the March’s house.  106.
Mr. Laurence?
Jo! They embrace - and then Mr. Laurence tries to explain:
I couldn't bring myself to... The house doesn’t seem right without her and I couldn’t go in knowing she wouldn’t be there. He begins crying. Jo takes his arm tenderly.

I know I am not half so good as my sister, but I'll be a friend to lean on, if you’1l let me. He gratefully accepts her help and they approach the hous together, an odd, sweet pair of friends. INT. MARCH HOUSE. JO & MEG’S ROOM/ATTIC. NIGHT/DAY. 1869. Jo starts awake - she looks around the room: she’s all al everyone is truly gone. She lights a candle. She goes to drawer where she keeps her writing, and pulls out the sta She feeds a published story into the fire. Then she burns more stories, printed, unpublished, half-finished, she bu them all. It is a potlatch, a total burning down of everything she has made up until this point. She finds one last piece, and is about to give it over to fire, when she reads on top: “For Beth.” She stops. Jo makes her way up to the attic, and sits in her old wri chair, looking at the story. She takes a fresh sheet of p and starts writing. She writes all night, and into the next day, piling up pa after page. She spreads them out in the attic, like a qui building outwards. Candles are lit and re-lit, the sun ri and sets. Marmee brings her some food and then leaves her alone. Jo nods off for a second then keeps writing. She revises, scratches out, she changes orders. She falls asleep on he blanket of papers.  107. She's re-connected with her childhood, and out of the dep of despair has found hope and inspiration. Jo finishes and carefully ties up the first few chapters this experiment and writes a letter to Mr. Dashwood:

(read to camera) Dear Mr. Dashwood: Enclosed are the first few chapters of a piece I’ve only begun working on. It could suit as a story for young people, but I think it is probably quite boring. However, I’m sending it to you just in case it has something of value, though I doubt it. INT. AUNT MARCH’S HOUSE. DAY. 1869. The empty rooms of Aunt March’s house -- nothing is left the deliciously cranky old lady. Furniture is covered ove and the loss is felt in the grand rooms. Amy, Jo and Meg around the big empty mansion.
I thought she hated me.
She could still hate you and leave you the house! Jo laughs.
What about you and John?
No, I don’t need a grand estate. Meg looks satisfied, and we know that she is, deeply. Suddenly, Jo lets out a WHOOP and runs through the house.
For heaven's /sake! /What are you doing?
(looking around) I should sell it, but I’d love to do something that would really make Aunt March turn in her grave.
I wouldn’t mind that.  108.
/Girls! /A nice turning, just a rotation, nothing terrible.
What will you do? Jo thinks for half a second, but she already knows:
I'd like to open a school. We never had a proper school, and now there are women’s colleges opening - there should be a school. For Daisy.
And what will Demi do?
I’1l open a school for boys and girls, both. Amy takes her sister’s arm on one side, while Meg is on t other side. They walk and talk confidentially.
What about writing?
(Jo turns bright red) What are you working on? What /about it?
I started something... but I don’t think it’s very good.
Everyone likes what you write.
(pointedly) No, they don’t.
I do.
It’s just about our little life.  109.
So? Who will be interested ina story of domestic struggles and joys? It doesn’t have any real importance.
Maybe we don’t see those things as important because people don’t write about them.
No, writing doesn’t confer importance, it reflects it.
I’m not sure. Perhaps writing will make them more important.
(looking at her, amused) When did you become so wise?
I always have been, you were just too busy noticing my faults.

Which weren’t there, of course. They lean their heads together and stroll through the hou INT. NEW YORK PUBLISHING OFFICE. DAY. 1869. Mr. Dashwood sits, reading the pages that Jo gave him. He finishes and then writes to her.
(read to camera) Dear Miss March: I have read the chapters you sent, and I have to agree that they aren’t very promising. But, please send us more stories of the scandalous variety, if you have any.

location: MARCH HOUSE. ATTIC./DINING ROOM. EARLY EVENING. 1869

text: Jo reads the note Mr. Dashwood sent:
Or, shall I say, your friend can. My apologies for the joke, I couldn't help it.  110. And she crumples it up. Just then, Marmee breaks her reve
Jo! Come down!
Coming! I’m starving! Jo stashes her writing and clomps down the stairs and hea straight for the table, not even looking around her. She down and grabs a piece of bread and takes a big bite.
Jo, you might want to wait..
But I’m famished.
Jo, dear, you have a guest.
I don’t know anyone.
I am so sorry to intrude. Jo hears his voice and bolts up.

(she bursts out laughing) It’s you! THE PAST. EXT. BOARDING HOUSE. NEW YORK. DAY. 1867. Jo, with all of her luggage, finds the address and rings doorbell. Friedrich opens it, he smiles down at this youn woman, with his handsome face and merry eyes -- she comes undone before even knowing it.
Hello.
Hello. I’m Josephine March. Jo. Just then, Mrs. Kirke pushes past him, with her two child
(to be delivered without stopping for breath, with infinite cheer and anxiety) Jo! Is that you?! Come in, come in!  111.

Your mother says that you’re a writer — how wonderful! I keep a diary, you know. This is Kitty and Minny. SMILE GIRLS. I see you’ve met our professor, he’s a very accomplished man, actually, it’s an interesting group here, lots of intellectuals and Europeans. You know I never thought I’d run a boarding house but here I am! How is that sweet mother of yours? She always had such great height, I never had that, she could reach anything... She leads Jo up through the stairs and Jo takes a quick glance backwards at Friedrich, as if to confirm that the she saw was real and not an apparition. She finds Friedri looking back up at her. She turns away again. BACK TO THE PRESENT. 1869.
Jo, I hope it is all right, I got your address from Mrs. Kirke -
Who are you? (to Amy) Who is he?
(backing away) I’m so sorry to intrude, I was close by and thought I’d, but I’1l be going...
- Please stay! We have more than enough room.
Can someone tell me who he is!?
I don’t want to be a burden.
It’s no burden at all.
(still stunned) Yes, of course. Please.  112.
(proprietary) I’m Laurie. And who are you?
I am Friedrich Bhaer.
(explaining) We were at the same boarding house together in New York.

Oh JO, he’s VERY handsome. Later: Everyone is talking. Father and Friedrich especially talk philosophy and religion and politics. Father obviously ve much likes him. Jo is glowing with happiness. Amy looks from Friedrich to Jo and from Jo to Friedrich. can see that there is love between them.
(to Friedrich) And you intend to stay in New York?

No, I’ve been offered a professorship in California - and as I have nothing keeping me here, I thought I might go West. It is new there, and they are less particular about immigrants. Jo has an unconscious sharp intake of breath. No one noti but Amy. Father continues oblivious:
Perhaps I should go West...
You aren’t an immigrant, so perhaps you should stay home. Everyone bursts out laughing. Father laughs at himself go naturedly.
Oh, I’m going.  113. INT. MARCH HOUSE. LIVING ROOM. DAY. 1869. Everyone relaxes after dinner, and Friedrich eyes the pia
This is a beautiful instrument. Which one of you plays? They all fall quiet.
It was my sister, Beth.
We all play a little.
But none so well as her...
It is very hard to lose a sister. I’m sorry.
Do you play?
I do, yes.
It would make us so happy if you played now, she wouldn’t want the piano to sit silent.
I don’t wish to offend.

Not in the least. He sits down and plays Bach - it is beautiful and elegant watches him, moved and deeply happy. The sound of his music plays over Friedrich saying his goodbyes and telling Jo, as he stands at the door:
Jo, if you ever come to California, I would love to see you.
I don’t know that I will, but thank you.  114.
(hurting, but accepting) Well, yes... goodbye.
Goodbye. It has started to rain, and he puts up his umbrella and trudges into the evening. The door closes. Jo turns back around to find everyone staring at her.
What?! Why are you all looking at me like that?
What a wonderful man. I hope he comes again, he would be a terrific friend for me.
(crying out) Oh Father, he wasn’t here for you!
No?
Jo! You love him!
I do not!
You do too! I may be half as smart as you are but I can see it so plainly, you love him. I have never seen you happier. What else is love? Doesn’t she love him Mr. Laurence?
That’s a good instinct, you love him.
Go get him. Laurie prepare the horses. We can catch him before he gets to the train.  115.
(standing) I’m coming too.
I’m not going!
You are. Amy is right.
